verses.text: In the spring of the year, at the time when kings go out to battle, Joab led out the army and devastated the land of the Ammonites and came to Rabbah and besieged it. But David remained in Jerusalem. And Joab struck Rabbah and destroyed it.
verses.comment: This follows the Hebrew text closely; 'In the spring of the year, at the time when kings go out to battle' echoes the literal phrase from the original.

verses.text: David took the crown of their king from his head. He found that it weighed a talent of gold, and there was a precious stone in it. It was placed on David’s head, and he brought out a great amount of spoil from the city.
verses.comment: The phrase 'a talent of gold' is about 75 pounds or 34 kilograms. The wording closely follows the Hebrew.

verses.text: He brought out the people who were in it and set them to labor with saws, iron picks, and axes. Thus David did to all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Translates the tools literally as in the Hebrew; 'labor with saws, iron picks, and axes.'

verses.text: After this, there arose war with the Philistines at Gezer. Then Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Sippai, who was one of the descendants of the giants, and they were subdued.
verses.comment: ‘Descendants of the giants’ renders the Hebrew ‘Rephaim,’ traditionally understood as a race of giants.

verses.text: Again there was war with the Philistines, and Elhanan the son of Jair struck down Lahmi the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear’s shaft was like a weaver’s beam.
verses.comment: The Hebrew text here clarifies Goliath’s relationship compared to Samuel, which can be ambiguous; the translation follows the 1 Chronicles reading.

verses.text: And there was again war at Gath, where there was a man of great stature, who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in all; and he also was descended from the giants.
verses.comment: ‘Descended from the giants’/‘Rephaim’ preserves the sense of the original.

verses.text: When he taunted Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimea, David’s brother, struck him down.
verses.comment: ‘Taunted Israel’ is a literal rendering of the Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: These were descended from the giants in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants.
verses.comment: The wording ‘descended from the giants’ keeps the lineage reference explicit as in the Hebrew.
